content.text:
# Timeline of Wyoming history

This timeline is a chronology of significant events in the history of the U.S. State of Wyoming and the historical area now occupied by the state.
__NOTOC__
2020s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2022||align=center|November 8||In the 2022 General Election, Wyoming voters elect Harriet Hageman as U.S. Representative and re-elect Mark Gordon as Governor. Republicans retain control of the Wyoming Legislature.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|2021||align=center|September 2||Wyoming U.S. Representative Liz Cheney is named Vice Chair of the United States House Select Committee on the January 6 Attack.
|-
|align=center|May 12||Wyoming U.S. Representative Liz Cheney is removed as Chair of the House Republican Conference.
|-
|align=center|January 13||Wyoming U.S. Representative Liz Cheney votes to impeach President Donald Trump.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|2020||align=center|November 3||In the 2020 General Election, Wyoming voters elect three U.S. Presidential Electors for President Donald Trump, elect Cynthia Lummis as the junior U.S. Senator, and re-elect Liz Cheney as U.S. Representative.  Republicans retain control of the Wyoming Legislature.
|-
|align=center|September 17||The Mullen Fire ignites  west of Centennial.  As many as 1,254 firefighters battle the wildfire as it spreads through Carbon County, Albany County, and Jackson County, Colorado, and consumes  of forest.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The 2020 United States census enumerates the population of the State of Wyoming, later determined to be 576,851, a 2.35% increase since the 2010 United States census. Wyoming remains the least populous of the 50 United States.
|}
2010s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|2019||align=center|January 7||Mark Gordon takes office as the thirty-third Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center|January 3||Liz Cheney takes office as the Wyoming U.S. Representative and is named Chair of the House Republican Conference.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2017||align=center|August 21||The solar eclipse of August 21, 2017 sweeps across Wyoming.  Huge crowds gather in Casper and Glendo to witness the total solar eclipse.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2011||align=center|January 3||Matt Mead takes office as the thirty-second Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2010||align=center|April 1||The 2010 United States census enumerates the population of the State of Wyoming, later determined to be 563,626, an increase of 14.1% since the 2000 United States census. Wyoming remains the least populous of the 50 U.S. states.
|}
2000s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2007||align=center|January 3||John Barrasso takes office as the junior Wyoming  U.S. Senator.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2003||align=center|January 6||Dave Freudenthal takes office as the thirty-first Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2001||align=center|January 20||Dick Cheney takes office as the forty-sixth Vice President of the United States.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2000||align=center|April 1||The 2000 United States census enumerates the population of the State of Wyoming, later determined to be 493,782, an increase of 8.9% since the 1990 United States census. Wyoming remains the least populous of the 50 U.S. states.
|}
1990s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1997||align=center|January 3||Mike Enzi takes office as the junior Wyoming U.S. Senator.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1995||align=center|January 2||Jim Geringer takes office as the thirtieth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1992||align=center|August 3||U.S. President George H. W. Bush signs into law an amendment to the National Trails System Act to designate the California National Historic Trail and Pony Express National Historic Trail as components of the National Trails System.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1990||align=center|April 1||The 1990 United States census enumerates the population of the State of Wyoming, later determined to be 453,588, a decrease of -3.4% since the 1980 United States census.  As its population decreases, Wyoming becomes the least populous of the 50 U.S. states.
|}
1980s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1989||align=center|March 22||U.S. President George H. W. Bush appoints Dick Cheney the seventeenth United States Secretary of Defense.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1988||align=center|November 8||The Town of Alpine is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|June 14||The first of over 200 wildfires begin burning in Yellowstone National Park and adjacent national forests. More than 9,000 firefighters battle the wildfires as they consume  of forest.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1987||align=center|January 5||Mike Sullivan takes office as the twenty-ninth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1984||align=center|November 27||The Town of Wright is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|March 8||The Town of Rolling Hills is incorporated.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1982||align=center|November 8||The Town of Bar Nunn is incorporated.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1980||align=center|April 1||The 1980 United States census enumerates the population of the State of Wyoming, later determined to be 469,557, an increase of 41.3% since the 1970 United States census. Wyoming remains the 49th most populous of the 50 U.S. states.
|}
1970s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
| rowspan="2" align="center" |1979||align=center|December 18||The Town of Hanna annexes the adjacent Town of Elmo.
|-
|align=center|July 16||An F3 tornado makes landfall in Cheyenne, killing 1 and injuring 40. It remains the most destructive tornado in the state's history.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1978||align=center|November 10||U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs the National Parks and Recreation Act of 1978 authorizing the Continental Divide National Scenic Trail, the Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail, and the Oregon National Historic Trail.
|-
|align=center|October 9||The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) designates Yellowstone National Park as one of the first 12 World Heritage Sites.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1977||align=center|September ||The City of Cody transfers Shoshone Cavern to the Bureau of Land Management.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1976||align=center|July 4||The State of Wyoming celebrates the Bicentennial of the United States of America.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1975||align=center|January 6||Edgar J. Herschler takes office as the twenty-eighth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1973||align=center|April 26||The Town of Midwest is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|February 13||The Town of La Barge is incorporated.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1972||align=center|October 23||U.S. President Richard Nixon issues a proclamation creating Fossil Butte National Monument.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1970||align=center|April 1||The 1970 United States census enumerates the population of the State of Wyoming, later determined to be 332,416, an increase of 0.7% since the 1960 United States census. Wyoming becomes the 49th most populous of the 50 U.S. states.
|}
1960s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1968||align=center|December 2||U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson signs An Act to establish a national trails system, and for other purposes, creating the National Trails System.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1967||align=center|January 2||Stanley K. Hathaway takes office as the twenty-seventh Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1966||align=center|October 15||U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson signs An Act to provide for the establishment of the Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area, and for other purposes.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1963||align=center|January 7||Clifford P. Hansen takes office as the twenty-sixth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1961||align=center|January 2||Jack R. Gage takes office as the twenty-fifth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1960||align=center|April 29||U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs An Act to revise the boundaries and change the name of the Fort Laramie National Monument, Wyoming, and for other purposes, expanding Fort Laramie National Monument and changing the name to Fort Laramie National Historic Site.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The 1960 United States census enumerates the population of the State of Wyoming, later determined to be 330,066, an increase of 13.6% since the 1950 United States census. Wyoming becomes the 48th most populous of the 50 U.S. states.
|}
1950s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1959||align=center|January 3||John J. Hickey takes office as the twenty-fourth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1957||align=center|spring ||Buffalo Bill State Park, Wyoming's first state park, opens.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1955||align=center|January 3||Milward Simpson takes office as the twenty-third Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1954||align=center|June 29||The Town of Frannie is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|June 17||U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs An Act to authorize the abolishment of the Shoshone Cavern National Monument and the transfer of the land therein to the city of Cody, Wyoming, for public recreational use, and for other purposes.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1953||align=center|January 3||Clifford J. Rogers takes office as the twenty-second Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1951||align=center|May 1||The Town of Hulett is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|January 1||Frank A. Barrett takes office as the twenty-first Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1950||align=center|September 14||U.S. President Harry Truman signs An Act to establish a new Grand Teton National Park in the State of Wyoming, and for other purposes, merging Jackson Hole National Monument into Grand Teton National Park.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The 1950 United States census enumerates the population of the State of Wyoming, later determined to be 290,529, an increase of 15.9% since the 1940 United States census. Wyoming remains the 47th most populous of the 48 U.S. states.
|}
1940s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1949||align=center|January 3||Arthur G. Crane takes office as the twentieth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1945||align=center|September 2||World War II ends as the Empire of Japan formally surrenders.
|-
|align=center|May 8||The war in Europe ends as the Greater German Empire formally surrenders.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1944||align=center|December 29||U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt vetoes House Resolution 2241, "To abolish the Jackson Hole National Monument as created by Presidential Proclamation Numbered 2578, dated March 15, 1943."
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1943||align=center|March 15||U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt issues Executive Proclamation Number 2578, creating Jackson Hole National Monument.
|-
|align=center|January 4||Lester C. Hunt takes office as the nineteenth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1942||align=center|November 3||The Town of Parco changes its name to the Town of Sinclair at the General Election of 1942.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1941||align=center|December 11||The United States declares war on the German Reich and the Italian Empire.
|-
|align=center|December 8||The United States declares war on the Empire of Japan and enters World War II.
|-
|align=center|March 10||U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt issues an executive order renaming Wyoming National Forest as the re-established Bridger National Forest.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1940||align=center|April 1||The 1940 United States census enumerates the population of the State of Wyoming, later determined to be 250,742, an increase of 11.2% since the 1930 United States census. Wyoming remains the 47th most populous of the 48 U.S. states.
|}
1930s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1939||align=center|January 2||Nels H. Smith takes office as the eighteenth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1938||align=center|July 16||U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating Fort Laramie National Monument.
|-
|align=center|April 18||The Town of La Grange is incorporated.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1937||align=center|July 22||U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs An Act to create the Farmers' Home Corporation, to promote more secure occupancy of farms and farm homes, to correct the economic instability resulting from some present forms of farm tenancy, and for other purposes, also known as the Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenant Act.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1935||align=center|August 6||The Town of Hanna is incorporated.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1933||align=center|May 3||U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appoints Nellie Tayloe Ross as the 28th Director of the United States Mint, the first woman to hold the post. She will hold the office for twenty years.
|-
|align=center|January 2||Leslie A. Miller takes office as the seventeenth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1932||align=center|January 1||The Town of Ten Sleep is incorporated.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1931||align=center|November 16||The Town of Green River passes the Green River ordinance that prohibits door-to-door selling.  Other towns across the country will adopt the ordinance.
|-
|align=center|February 18||Alonzo M. Clark takes office as the sixteenth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1930||align=center|September 13||The Town of Albin is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The 1930 United States census enumerates the population of the State of Wyoming, later determined to be 225,565, an increase of 16.0% since the 1920 United States census. Wyoming remains the 47th most populous of the 48 U.S. states.
|}
1920s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1929||align=center|July 10||U.S. President Calvin Coolidge signs An Act to establish the Grand Teton National Park in the State of Wyoming, and for other purposes.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1927||align=center|January 3||Frank C. Emerson takes office as the fifteenth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1925||align=center|November 3||The Town of Edgerton is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The Town of Parco is incorporated. (Changed name to the Town of Sinclair on November 3, 1942.)
|-
|align=center|January 5||Nellie Tayloe Ross takes office as the fourteenth Governor of State of Wyoming. She becomes the first woman to be sworn in as governor of a U.S. state.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1924||align=center|October 2||Frank Lucas takes office as the thirteenth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center|June 2||U.S. President Calvin Coolidge signs An Act To authorize the Secretary of the Interior to issue certificates of citizenship to Indians, also known as the Indian Citizenship Act of 1924, finally granting full United States Citizenship to all Native Americans born in the United States.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1923||align=center|May 14||U.S. President Warren G. Harding issues an executive order abolishing Bridger National Forest and transferring its land to Wyoming National Forest. (Wyoming National Forest will be renamed Bridger National Forest on March 10, 1941.)
|-
|align=center|January 1||William B. Ross takes office as the twelfth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1922||align=center|May 1||The Town of Glendo is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|April 15||Wyoming U.S. Senator John B. Kendrick introduces a resolution calling for an investigation into the Teapot Dome scandal.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1921||align=center|February 15||The State of Wyoming creates two new counties:Sublette County from portions of Fremont County and Lincoln County; andTeton County from a portion of Lincoln County.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1920||align=center|April 1||The 1920 United States census enumerates the population of the State of Wyoming, later determined to be 194,402, an increase of 33.2% since the 1910 United States census. Wyoming becomes the 47th most populous of the 48 U.S. states.
|}
1910s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1919||align=center|September 28||The Town of Ranchester is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|January 6||Robert D. Carey takes office as the eleventh Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1918||align=center|November 11||An armistice halts the Great War.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1917||align=center|April 6||The United States declares war on the German Empire and enters the Great War.
|-
|align=center|February 26||Frank L. Houx takes office as the tenth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center|January 29||The Town of Elmo is incorporated. (Annexed by the adjacent Town of Hanna on December 18, 1979.)
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1916||align=center|August 25||U.S. President Woodrow Wilson signs An Act To establish a National Park Service, and for other purposes.
|-
|align=center|March 8||The Town of Van Tassell is incorporated.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1915||align=center|January 4||John B. Kendrick takes office as the ninth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=5|1914||align=center|August 7||The Town of Jackson is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|August 4||The Town of Marbleton is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|August 3||The Town of Opal is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|May 14||The Town of Dubois is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|April 21||The Town of Wamsutter is incorporated.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1913||align=center|July 1||The Town of Kaycee is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The Town of Big Piney is incorporated.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1912||align=center|February 12||The Town of Pinedale is incorporated.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1911||align=center|June 30||U.S. President William Howard Taft issues proclamations creating Washakie National Forest and Bridger National Forest. (Bridger National Forest will be abolished May 14, 1923, but re-established March 10, 1941.)
|-
|align=center|February 21||The State of Wyoming creates seven new counties:Campbell County from portions of Crook County and Weston County;Goshen County from a portion of Laramie County;Hot Springs County from portions of Big Horn County, Fremont County, and Hot Springs County;Lincoln County from a portion of Uinta County;Niobrara County from a portion of Converse County;Platte County from a portion of Laramie County; andWashakie County from a portion of Big Horn County.
|-
|align=center|January 2||Joseph M. Carey takes office as the eighth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=5|1910||align=center|July 1||U.S. President William Howard Taft issues a proclamation re-establishing Medicine Bow National Forest.
|-
|align=center|June 28||U.S. President William Howard Taft issues a proclamation creating Palisade National Forest.
|-
|align=center|May 31||The Town of Cokeville is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|May 10||The Town of Powell is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The 1910 United States census enumerates the population of the State of Wyoming, later determined to be 145,965, an increase of 57.7% since the 1900 United States census. Wyoming becomes the 45th most populous of the 46 U.S. states.
|}
1900s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=7|1909||align=center|September 24||The State of Wyoming creates Park County from a portion of Big Horn County.
|-
|align=center|September 21||U.S. President William Howard Taft issues an executive order creating Shoshone Cavern National Monument.
|-
|align=center|June 6||The Town of Medicine Bow is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|June 1||The Town of Lost Cabin is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|May 14||The Town of Pine Bluffs is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|May 12||The Town of Rock River is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|February 4||The Town of Hudson is incorporated.
|-
|align=center rowspan=8|1908||align=center|October 18||The Town of Upton is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|July 2||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues an executive order creating Bighorn National Forest.
|-
|align=center|July 1||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues executive orders creating Targhee National Forest, Teton National Forest, Wyoming National Forest, Bonneville National Forest, Ashley National Forest, and Shoshone National Forest.
|-
|align=center|June 30||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues an executive order creating Cheyenne National Forest.
|-
|align=center|June 26||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues an executive order creating Sundance National Forest.
|-
|align=center|June 25||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues an executive order creating Hayden National Forest.
|-
|align=center|May 11||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues an executive order creating Lewis and Clark Cavern National Monument.
|-
|align=center|March 28||Two coal gas explosions in the Union Pacific Coal Company's Hanna Mine No. 1 kill 59 miners.
|-
|align=center rowspan=4|1907||align=center|July 8||The Town of Sheridan is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|March 1||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating the Bear Lodge Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center|January 15||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating the Caribou Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center|January 4||The Town of Torrington is incorporated.
|-
|align=center rowspan=9|1906||align=center|November 5||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating the Sierra Madre Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|October 2||The Town of Moorcroft is incorporated.
|-
|The Town of Riverton is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|September 24||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating Devils Tower National Monument, the first United States National Monument created under the Antiquities Act.
|-
|align=center|July 2||The Town of Dayton is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|June 8||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt signs An Act For the preservation of American antiquities, also known as the Antiquities Act of 1906, giving the President of the United States the authority to create national monuments on federal lands to protect significant natural, cultural, or scientific features.
|-
|align=center|April 2||The Town of Shoshoni is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|March 30||The Town of Worland is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|January 16||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt  issues a proclamation creating the Uinta Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1905||align=center|November 18||The Town of Wheatland is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|January 2||Bryant B. Brooks takes office as the seventh Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1903||align=center|June 30||A coal gas explosion in the Union Pacific Coal Company's Hanna Mine No. 1 kills 169 miners.
|-
|align=center|April 28||Fenimore Chatterton takes office as the sixth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=4|1902||align=center|July 7||The Town of Basin is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|May 22||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating the Yellowstone Forest Reserve and the Medicine Bow Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center|April 24||The Town of Afton is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|April 4||The Town of Guernsey is incorporated.
|-
|align=center rowspan=4|1901||align=center|October 1||The Town of Cody is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|August 7||The Town of Meeteetse is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|April 2||The Town of Encampment is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|March 2||The Town of Diamondville is incorporated.
|-
|align=center rowspan=5|1900||align=center|October 10||U.S. President William McKinley issues a proclamation creating the Crow Creek Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center|July 1||The Town of Saratoga is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|April 28||A coal gas explosion in the Union Pacific Coal Company's Hanna Mine No. 1 kills miner Henry Ward.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The 1900 United States census enumerates the population of the State of Wyoming, later determined to be 92,531, an increase of 47.9% since the 1890 United States census. Wyoming becomes the 44th most populous of the 45 U.S. states.
|-
|align=center|February 17||The Town of Hartville is incorporated.
|}
1890s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1899||align=center|January 23||The Town of Kemmerer is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|January 21||The Town of Thermopolis is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|January 2||DeForest Richards takes office as the fifth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=5|1898||align=center|December 10||The United States of America and the Kingdom of Spain sign the Treaty of Paris of 1898 to end the Spanish–American War.
|-
|align=center|September 19||U.S. President William McKinley issues a proclamation creating the Black Hills Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center|August 12||The United States of America and the Kingdom of Spain sign a Protocol of Peace.
|-
|align=center|June 17||The Town of Lusk is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|April 23||The Kingdom of Spain declares war on the United States of America.  The United States declares war on Spain two days later.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1897||align=center|September 23||Cheyenne hosts the first Cheyenne Frontier Days.
|-
|align=center|February 22||U.S. President Grover Cleveland issues proclamations creating the Teton Forest Reserve and the Big Horn Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1895||align=center|January 7||William A. Richards takes office as the fourth Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1893||align=center|January 2||John E. Osborne takes office as the third Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1892||align=center|January 7||The Town of Gillette is incorporated.
|-
|align=center rowspan=4|1891||align=center|November 24||Amos W. Barber takes office as the second Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center|June 10||The Town of Green River is re-incorporated under the laws of the State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center|March 30||U.S. President Benjamin Harrison issues a proclamation creating the Yellowstone Park Timber Land Reserve, the first United States National Forest.
|-
|align=center|March 3||U.S. President Benjamin Harrison signs An act to repeal timber-culture laws, and for other purposes, also known as the Forest Reserve Act of 1891, giving the President of the United States the authority to create protected national forests on federal lands.
|-
|align=center rowspan=5|1890||align=center|October 11||Territorial Governor Francis E. Warren takes office as the first Governor of State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center|July 17||The Town of Lander is incorporated.
|-  style="background-color:#FFDDDD;"
|align=center|July 10||U.S. President Benjamin Harrison signs An Act to provide for the admission of the State of Wyoming into the Union, and for other purposes.  The Territory of Wyoming becomes the State of Wyoming, the 44th U.S. state and the first U.S. state to grant women the right to vote.  Wyoming later becomes known as the Equality State.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The 1890 United States census enumerates the population of the Territory of Wyoming, later determined to be 62,555, an increase of 200.9% since the 1880 United States census. Wyoming becomes the fifth most populous of the six U.S. territories.
|-
|align=center|March 12||The Territory of Wyoming creates two new counties:Big Horn County from portions of Fremont County, Johnson County, and Sheridan County; andWeston County from a portion of Crook County.
|}
1880s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1889||align=center|October 25||The Town of Newcastle is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|July 8||The Town of Casper is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|April 9||U.S. President Benjamin Harrison appoints Francis E. Warren the tenth (and last) Governor of Territory of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1888||align=center|June 1||The Town of Evanston is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|March 9||The Territory of Wyoming creates three new counties:Converse County from portions of Albany County and Laramie County;Natrona County from a portion of Carbon County; andSheridan County from a portion of Johnson County.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1887||align=center|October 5||The Town of Sundance is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|June 8||The Town of Douglas is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|January 24||U.S. President Grover Cleveland appoints Thomas Moonlight the ninth Governor of Territory of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=4|1886||align=center|December 20||U.S. President Grover Cleveland appoints Elliot S.N. Morgan the eighth Governor of Territory of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center|November 11||U.S. President Grover Cleveland appoints George W. Baxter the seventh Governor of Territory of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center|March 12||The Town of Rawlins is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|March 4||The Territory of Wyoming establishes the University of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1885||align=center|September 2||White immigrant miners riot and kill 28 Chinese immigrant miners and burn 78 homes in the Rock Springs massacre.
|-
|align=center|February 28||U.S. President Chester A. Arthur appoints Francis E. Warren the sixth Governor of Territory of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center|January 13||U.S. President Chester A. Arthur appoints Elliot S.N. Morgan the fifth Governor of Territory of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1884||align=center|April 4||The Town of Buffalo is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The Territory of Wyoming creates Fremont County from a portion of Sweetwater County.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1882||align=center|July 18||U.S. President Chester A. Arthur appoints William Hale the fourth Governor of Territory of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1880||align=center|April 1||The 1880 United States census enumerates the population of the Territory of Wyoming, later determined to be 20,789, an increase of 128.0% since the 1880 United States census. Wyoming becomes the least populous of the eight U.S. territories.
|}
1870s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1879||align=center|December 13||The Territory of Wyoming changes the name of Pease County to Johnson County.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1878||align=center|April 10||U.S. President Rutherford B. Hayes appoints John Wesley Hoyt the third Governor of Territory of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1876||align=center|July 4||The Territory of Wyoming celebrates the Centennial of the United States of America while still reeling from the defeat of Lieutenant Colonel George Armstrong Custer and the 7th Cavalry Regiment at the Battle of the Little Bighorn on June 26.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1875||align=center|December 8||The Territory of Wyoming creates two new counties:Crook County from portions of Albany County and Laramie County; andPease County from portions of Albany County, Carbon County and Sweetwater County.
|-
|align=center|March 1||U.S. President Ulysses S. Grant appoints John Milton Thayer the second Governor of Territory of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1874||align=center|January 13||The Town of Laramie is incorporated.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1872||align=center|March 1||U.S. President Ulysses S. Grant signs An Act to set apart a certain tract of land lying near the headwaters of the Yellowstone River as a public park, creating Yellowstone National Park, the world's first national park.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1870||align=center|April 1||The 1870 United States census enumerates the population of the Territory of Wyoming, later determined to be 9,118. Wyoming becomes the least populous of the nine U.S. territories.
|}
1860s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=5|1869||align=center|December 16||The Union Pacific Railroad arrives in Evanston.
|-
|align=center|December 10||The first session of the Wyoming Territorial Legislature meets in Cheyenne.  The legislature passes and Territorial Governor Campbell signs an act to re-incorporate the Town of Cheyenne, Wyoming Territory, and an act granting white women the right to vote, the first U.S. state or territory to grant suffrage to women.
|-
|align=center|December 1||Wyoming Territorial Governor John Allen Campbell creates a fifth original county: Uinta County.
|-
|align=center|May 24||John Wesley Powell launches the Powell Geographic Expedition from Green River.
|-
|align=center|April 5||U.S. President Ulysses S. Grant appoints John Allen Campbell the first Governor of Territory of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center rowspan=6|1868||align=center|December 16||The provisional legislature of Wyoming creates four original counties:Albany County,Carbon County,Laramie County (previously Laramie County, Dakota Territory), andSweetwater County (previously Carter County, Dakota Territory).
|-
|align=center|October 1||The Union Pacific Railroad arrives in Green River.
|-
|align=center|August 21||The Town of Green River, Wyoming Territory is incorporated under the laws of the previous Territory of Dakota. (Re-incorporated under the laws of the State of Wyoming on June 10, 1891.)
|-
|align=center|August 8||The Union Pacific Railroad arrives in Rawlins Springs.
|-  style="background-color:#DDFFDD;"
|align=center|July 25||U.S. President Andrew Johnson signs An Act to provide a temporary Government for the Territory of Wyoming which creates the Territory of Wyoming from the portion of the Territory of Dakota west of the 27th meridian west from Washington, and the portions of Territory of Idaho and the Territory of Utah east of the 34th meridian west from Washington.  The boundaries of the Territory of Wyoming remain unchanged to the present-day State of Wyoming.
|-
|align=center|May 4||The Union Pacific Railroad arrives in Laramie.
|-
|align=center rowspan=6|1867||align=center|December 27||The Territory of Dakota creates Carter County, Dakota Territory from a portion of Laramie County, Dakota Territory.
|-
|align=center|November 13||The Union Pacific Railroad arrives in Cheyenne.
|-
|align=center|September 8||The United States Army establishes Fort D.A. Russell three miles (5 km) west of Cheyenne to protect the railroad.
|-
|align=center|August 8||The Town of Cheyenne, Dakota Territory (formerly Crow Creek Crossing) is incorporated. (Re-incorporated under the laws of the Territory of Wyoming on December 10, 1869.)
|-
|align=center|July 5||The Union Pacific Railroad plats the townsite of Crow Creek Crossing, Dakota Territory.
|-
|align=center|January 9||The Territory of Dakota creates Laramie County, Dakota Territory.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1865||align=center|May 9||U.S. President Andrew Johnson proclaims the end of the American Civil War.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1864||align=center|summer ||Civil engineer James A. Evans of the Union Pacific Railroad locates a pass in the Black Hills (later the Laramie Mountains) of the Territory of Dakota through which the Transcontinental Railroad could pass.
|-
|align=center|May 26||U.S. President Abraham Lincoln signs An Act to provide a temporary Government for the Territory of Montana.  In addition to creating the free Territory of Montana, the act transfers the portion of the Territory of Idaho "included within the following boundaries, to wit: commencing at a point formed by the intersection of the thirty-third degree of longitude west from Washington with the forty-first degree of north latitude; thence along said thirty-third degree of longitude to the crest of the Rocky Mountains; thence northward along the said crest of the Rocky Mountains to its intersection with the forty-fourth degree and thirty minutes of north latitude; thence eastward along said forty-fourth degree thirty minutes north latitude to the thirty-fourth degree of longitude west from Washington; thence northward along said thirty-fourth degree of longitude to its intersection with the forty-fifth degree north latitude; thence eastward along said forty-fifth degree of north latitude to its intersection with the twenty-seventh degree of longitude west from Washington; thence south along said twenty-seventh degree of longitude west from Washington to the forty-first degree north latitude; thence west along said forty-first degree of latitude to the place of beginning," back to the Territory of Dakota.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1863||align=center|March 3||U.S. President Abraham Lincoln signs An Act to provide a Temporary Government for the Territory of Idaho.  The free Territory of Idaho encompasses all of the future State of Wyoming except the southwest corner lying south of the 43rd parallel north and west of the 27th meridian west from Washington which remains in the Territory of Utah.
|-
|align=center rowspan=5|1861||align=center|June 6||Jefferson Territorial Governor Robert Williamson Steele proclaims the Territory of Jefferson officially disbanded.
|-
|align=center|April 12||The American Civil War begins with the Battle of Fort Sumter.
|-
|align=center|March 4||Abraham Lincoln assumes office as the 16th President of the United States.
|-
|align=center|March 2||Outgoing U.S. President James Buchanan signs An Act to provide a temporary government for the Territory of Dakota, and to create the office of surveyor general therein.  The free Territory of Dakota encompasses the northeast portion of the future State of Wyoming lying north of the 43rd parallel north and east of the Continental Divide of the Americas.  South of the 43rd parallel north, the Territory of Nebraska is extended westward from the Continental Divide of the Americas to the 27th meridian west from Washington, annexing the eastern portions of the Territory of Utah and the Territory of Washington.
|-
|align=center|February 8||The seven secessionist slave states create the Confederate States of America.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1860||align=center|November 6||Abraham Lincoln is elected President of the United States.  Seven slave states will secede from the United States of America before February 8, 1861.
|}
1850s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1859||align=center|October 24||Voters of the Pike's Peak goldfields approve the establishment of the Provisional Government of the Territory of Jefferson. The proposed territory includes the portion of the future State of Wyoming south of the 43rd parallel north and east of the 110th meridian west.
|-
|align=center|February 14||U.S. President James Buchanan signs An Act for the Admission of Oregon into the Union. The Territory of Washington now includes the western portion of the future State of Wyoming lying north of the 42nd parallel north and southwest of the Continental Divide of the Americas.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1854||align=center|May 30||U.S. President Franklin Pierce signs An Act to Organize the Territories of Nebraska and Kansas.  The Territory of Nebraska includes all of the future State of Wyoming northeast of the Continental Divide of the Americas.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1853||align=center|March 2||U.S. President Millard Fillmore signs An Act to establish the Territorial Government of Washington.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1851||align=center|April 5||The State of Deseret dissolves and yields to the Territory of Utah.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1850||align=center|September 9||The Territory of New Mexico and the Territory of Utah are established as part of the Compromise of 1850. U.S. President Millard Fillmore signs An Act to establish a Territorial Government for Utah.  The Territory of Utah includes the southwestern portion of the future State of Wyoming lying south of the 42nd parallel north and west of the Continental Divide of the Americas.
|-
|align=center|summer||Jim Bridger leads the Stansbury Expedition across a mountain pass on the Continental Divide of the Americas near the south Great Divide Basin bifurcation point, later known as Bridger Pass. Bridger Pass will become the crossing point for the Overland Trail and the Pony Express.
|}
1840s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1849||align=center|June 26||The U.S. Army purchases Fort John from the American Fur Company for $4,000 and renames it Fort Laramie. The fort becomes the headquarters for the Regiment of Mounted Rifles.  With Army protection, Fort Laramie becomes a major stop on the Emigrant Trail, the Bozeman Trail, Pony Express route, the Deadwood and Cheyenne Stage route, and the route of the first transcontinental telegraph.
|-
|align=center|March 10||The Mormon settlers of the Great Salt Lake Valley form the Provisional Government of the State of Deseret. Brigham Young is elected Governor. Deseret encompasses almost all of the present U.S. states of Utah and Nevada, and portions of Oregon, Idaho, Wyoming, Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, and California, although only the Wasatch Front was occupied. Although the proposed State of Deseret includes the southwestern portion of the future State of Wyoming, it has no actual presence in the region. Deseret served as the de facto government of the Wasatch Front until the Provisional State was dissolved on April 4, 1851.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1848||align=center|August 14||U.S. President James K. Polk signs An Act to Establish the Territorial Government of Oregon.  The Territory of Oregon includes the western portion of the future State of Wyoming lying north of the 42nd parallel north and southwest of the Continental Divide of the Americas.  The rest of the future state remains unorganized United States territory.
|-
|align=center|February 2||The United States and United Mexican States sign the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo to end the Mexican–American War.  Mexico relinquishes all of its northern territories.  All land in the future State of Wyoming becomes unorganized United States territory.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1846||align=center|May 13||The United States declares war on the Mexican Republic.
|-
|align=center|February 14||The State of Texas cedes the territorial claims of the Republic of Texas to the United States.  The boundaries of the State of Texas within those territorial claims remain undefined.  The United States now claims the Rio Grande as its border with Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1845||align=center|December 29||The United States admits the Republic of Texas to the Union as the slave State of Texas but declines to define its borders.  The Mexican Republic maintains that Texas is still its territory by the Treaty of Limits of 1828 and states that it will fight to regain Texas.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1842||align=center|spring ||Jim Bridger and Louis Vasquez establish Fort Bridger along Blacks Fork of the Green River in the Mexican territory of Alta California. Fort Bridger will become an important stop on the Emigrant Trail.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1841||align=center|autumn ||The American Fur Company completes a $10,000 adobe replacement for Fort William now named Fort John.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1840||align=center|autumn ||Lancaster Lupton establishes Fort Platte  north of Fort William at the confluence of the Laramie River and the North Platte River.
|}
1830s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1836||align=center|May 14||Texians force captured General Santa Anna to sign the coerced Treaties of Velasco recognizing the independence of the Republic of Texas. Mexico neither acknowledges nor ratifies these treaties. Based upon these treaties, the Republic of Texas claims as its eastern and northern border the Adams–Onís border with the United States and as its western and southern border the Rio Grande to its headwaters, thence north along meridian 107°32′35″ west to the Adams–Onís border with the United States. The disputed region will later become portions of the future U.S. states of Wyoming, Colorado, Kansas, Oklahoma, Texas, and New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1834||align=center|May 31||William Sublette and Robert Campbell establish Fort William at the confluence of the Laramie River and the North Platte River. Fort William is the first American settlement in the future State of Wyoming and will become an important stop on the Emigrant Trail.
|}
1820s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1828||align=center|January 12||The United States and the United Mexican States sign the Treaty of Limits affirming the boundaries set by the Adams–Onís Treaty of 1819.
|-
|align=center rowspan=4|1821||align=center|August 24||Ferdinand VII of Spain signs the Treaty of Córdoba recognizing the independence of the Mexican Empire.  The southwestern portion of the future State of Wyoming lying south of the 42nd parallel north and west of the Continental Divide of the Americas becomes part of the Mexican territory of Alta California, although there is no Mexican presence in the region.
|-
|align=center|August 10||The State of Missouri is admitted to the Union.  The rest of the Territory of Missouri becomes unorganized United States territory.
|-
|align=center|March 2||U.S. President James Monroe signs An Act to authorize the people of the Missouri territory to form a constitution and state government, and for the admission of such state into the Union on an equal footing with the original states, and to prohibit slavery in certain territories.
|-
|align=center|February 22||The Adams–Onís Treaty of 1819 takes effect.  All land in the future State of Wyoming north of the 42nd parallel north or east of the meridian 106°20'35" west becomes part of the Territory of Missouri. Land south of the 42nd parallel north and west of the meridian 106°20'35" west remains part of the New Spain (Nueva España) province of New Mexico (Santa Fe de Nuevo México).
|}
1810s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1819||align=center|February 22||The United States and the restored Kingdom of Spain sign the Adams–Onís Treaty.  The United States relinquinshes its claim to land west of the 100th meridian west of Greenwich and southwest of the Arkansas River and south of the 42nd parallel north.  Spain relinquishes Florida and all claims to land north of the 42nd parallel in North America.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1814||align=center| ||William Clark publishes ''A Map of Lewis and Clark's Track Across the Western Portion of North America from the Mississippi to the Pacific Ocean'' which includes the route of John Colter's explorations in 1807–1808.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1812||align=center|October 22||Robert Stuart and six companions from the Pacific Fur Company cross South Pass, the lowest point on the Continental Divide of the Americas between the Central Rocky Mountains and the Southern Rocky Mountains.  South Pass will become the crossing point for the Oregon Trail, the California Trail, and the Mormon Trail.
|-
|align=center|June 4||U.S. President James Madison signs An Act providing for the government of the territory of Missouri. The Territory of Louisiana is renamed the Territory of Missouri. The Territory of Missouri includes all land in the future State of Wyoming northeast of the Continental Divide of the Americas.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1810||align=center|August 1||Mexican priest Miguel Gregorio Antonio Ignacio Hidalgo-Costilla y Gallaga Mandarte Villaseñor (Hidalgo) proclaims the independence of Mexico from the Napoleonic Kingdom of Spain in the village of Dolores.
|}
1800s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1807||align=center|autumn||Mountain man John Colter becomes the first person from the United States to enter the future State of Wyoming. Colter's description of geysers, fumaroles, and mudpots along the Shoshone River led to the area being known as Colter's Hell.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1805||align=center|March 3||U.S. President Thomas Jefferson signs An Act further providing for the government of the district of Louisiana.  The District of Louisiana is reorganized as the self-governing Territory of Louisiana. The Territory of Louisiana includes all land in the future State of Wyoming northeast of the Continental Divide of the Americas.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1804||align=center|October 1||The District of Louisiana is organized under the jurisdiction of the Territory of Indiana.
|-
|align=center|March 26||U.S. President Thomas Jefferson signs An Act erecting Louisiana into two territories, and providing for the temporary government thereof.  The portion of the Louisiana Purchase north of the 33rd parallel north is designated the military District of Louisiana.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1803||align=center|December 20||The French Republic turns its colony of La Louisiane over to the United States.  All land in the future State of Wyoming northeast of the Continental Divide of the Americas becomes unorganized United States territory.
|-
|align=center|April 30||The United States and the French Republic sign the Louisiana Purchase Treaty.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1800||align=center|October 1||Under pressure from Napoléon Bonaparte, the Kingdom of Spain transfers the colony of la Luisiana back to the French Republic with the secret Third Treaty of San Ildefonso.
|}
1790s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|}
1780s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1783||align=center|September 3||The Treaty of Paris is signed in Paris by representatives of King George III of Great Britain and representatives of the United States of America.  The treaty affirms the independence of the United States and sets the Mississippi River as its western boundary.
|}
1770s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-  style="background-color:#EEEEFF;"
|align=center|1776||align=center|July 4||Representatives of the thirteen United States of America sign the Declaration of Independence from the Kingdom of Great Britain.
|}
1760s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center|1762||align=center|November 13||Fearing the loss of its American territories in the Seven Years' War, the Kingdom of France transfers its colony of La Louisiane to the Kingdom of Spain with the secret Treaty of Fontainebleau.
|}
1690s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|}
1680s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center|1682||align=center|April 9||René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle, claims the Mississippi River and its watershed for the Kingdom of France and names the region La Louisiane in honor of King Louis XIV. The Mississippi Basin is later determined to be the fourth most extensive on Earth and includes lands inhabited by hundreds of thousands of native peoples and lands previously claimed by Spain, France, and England. The Louisiane claim includes all land in the future State of Wyoming northeast of the Continental Divide of the Americas. This will set up a rivalry among native peoples, France, Spain, and eventually the United States in the area.
|}
1590s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center|1598||align=center|July 12||Don Juan de Oñate Salazar establishes the New Spain (Nueva España) colony of Santa Fe de Nuevo Méjico at the village of San Juan de los Caballeros adjacent to the Ohkay Owingeh Pueblo at the confluence of the Rio Grande (río Bravo) and the río Chama. At its greatest extent, the colony encompassed all of the present U.S. state of New Mexico and portions of Arizona, Utah, Colorado, Wyoming, Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma, Texas, and the Mexican state of Chihuahua.
|}
1540s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1541||align=center|June 28||A Spanish military expedition led by Hernando de Soto, Governor of Cuba, become the first Europeans to cross the Mississippi River.
|}
1510s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center|1513||align=center|September 29||Spanish conquistador Vasco Núñez de Balboa crosses the Isthmus of Panama and arrives on the shore of a sea that he names Mar del Sur (the South Sea, later named the Pacific Ocean).  He claims the sea and all adjacent lands for the Queen of Castile.  This includes the portion of the future State of Wyoming southwest of the Continental Divide of the Americas.
|}
1490s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center|1493||align=center|May 5||Pope Alexander VI (born Roderic de Borja in Valencia) issues the papal bull Inter caetera which splits the non-Christian world into two halves.  The eastern half goes to the King of Portugal for his exploration, conquest, conversion, and exploitation.  The western half (including all of North America) goes to the Queen of Castile and the King of Aragon for their exploration, conquest, conversion, and exploitation.  The indigenous peoples of the Americas have no idea that any of these people exist.
|-
|align=center|1492||align=center|October 12||Genoese seaman Cristòffa Cómbo (Christopher Columbus) leading an expedition for Queen Isabella I of Castile lands on the Lucayan island of Guanahani that he renames San Salvador.  This begins the Spanish conquest of the Americas.
|}
Before 1492
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Era||Event
|-
|align=center|||During a centuries long period of warming, ice-age Paleoamericans from Beringia begin using the ice-free corridor east of the Rocky Mountains to migrate throughout the Americas.
|}
